author: thebeastgoeson

print_settings.Notes:: The nose cone takes about 2 hours to print while the tail sections can take between 4 and 6 hours depending on your settings.

description.text:
Using the nose cone and tail sections from this project, in addition to some easily accessible cardboard tubes and other supplies, you can build cheap model rockets that enable you to test a variety of fin configurations. These rockets are designed to work with standard Estes solid rocket motors (we recommend A8-3).

This project has been targeted at high school and middle school students, with a presentation that enables a physics or engineering class to hypothesize about the optimal fin configurations for height and compare the actual results to calculated ideals.

For a slow-motion video of the launch, I've attached the following video.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

Variable per student specification

Notes:

The tail cones do best printing upside down, with the fins pointing upwards - this keeps the tail cone free of FOD that will keep you from inserting the motor easily. The cones were processed with MeshMixer to print in this configuration, so support is not necessary.

The nose cone takes about 2 hours to print while the tail sections can take between 4 and 6 hours depending on your settings.

Additional Supplies

In addition to the 3D printed parts, each rocket will require the following parts (sourcing suggestions and construction instructions are at the end):
1 Toilet Paper Tube
1 Paper Clip (regular sized)
1 Eye Screw (5mm eye, minimum)
1 Recovery Parachute with Shock Cord
1 Estes A8-3 Rocket Engine w/igniter
8 pc. Recovery Wadding

Many of the parts are available in bulk packaging. To launch, a suitable launch platform (Estes 302215) and Launch Controller (Estes 302220 + AA batteries) are needed.

These models were all designed using #OnShape and are constrained in size to be printed on the #MakerbotMini. The nose cones and tail cones were sized to fit the cardboard tube found at the center of a roll of toilet paper. In case the tube that is found in your locally sourced toilet paper is of a different diameter, the OnShape document is linked here.

Project Name

TP Tube Rockets

Overview and Background

The flight performance of unguided model rockets are determined by factors of aerodynamics, weight, and engine thrust. This project provides several different configurations to experimentally test these factors in a cost and time-effective manner.

In the context of a science classroom lesson, differing tail fin designs can be selected to influence the amount of stabilizing drag on a particular rocket. Two of the provided tail cone models induce spin for gyroscopic stabilization, similar to a spiraling football. They have the same planform as the “Shark Fin” model, so direct comparisons can be made. Modifying build parameters will affect the weight and center of gravity for a rocket. The thrust is standardized by use of a common rocket engine (An Estes A8-3 is recommended for classroom use).

Independent of the classroom setting, makers can construct their own model rockets for less than the cost of a typical rocket kit. More powerful engines (up to Estes C6 size) can be used for higher altitude launches.

Objectives

Upon completion of this lesson, students will demonstrate an understanding of the impact of weight and drag on the behavior of rockets. They will gain an understanding of thrust, be able to demonstrate skills in reading thrust vs. time graphs, and understand the equations of motion and Newtonian physics as they apply to this topic.

Audience

This project is intended for middle to high school aged students. The topic and materials can be differentiated to accommodate the level of the students. Mathematics can be easily incorporated for students throughout the age range.

Subjects

Math and Science

Standards

NGSS:

  • MS-PS1-6 Matter and its Interactions
    Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.*

  • MS-PS2-2 Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
    Plan an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an object’s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object.

  • MS-PS2-4 Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
    Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.

  • MS-PS2-5 Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
    Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on each other even though the objects are not in contact.

  • MS-PS3-1 Energy
    Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.

  • MS-PS3-5 Energy
    Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.

  • MS-ETS1-2 Engineering Design
    Evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

  • HS-PS2-1 Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
    Analyze data to support the claim that Newton’s second law of motion describes the mathematical relationship among the net force on a macroscopic object, its mass, and its acceleration.

  • HS-PS3-1 Energy
    Create a computational model to calculate the change in the energy of one component in a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) and energy flows in and out of the system are known.

  • HS-PS3-3 Energy
    Design, build, and refine a device that works within given constraints to convert one form of energy into another form of energy.
Lesson/Activity

To prepare for the lesson, acquire the additional non-printed parts and print the nose cones for each rocket before starting the lesson. Estes rockets, has a lot of helpful information, including standards-aligned lesson plans, at their website.

Introduce the general concept of how rockets work. NASA is a great resource with a pictorial history of rockets as well as the behavior of model rockets.

Model rocket use small solid fuel motors. For this project, the thrust provided will be the same for all rockets. The performance of a rocket will be determined by the apogee or maximum height that the rocket achieves from launch. Given a standardized motor with relatively uniform thrust output, the performance of each rocket will be determined by aerodynamic and mass factors. For aerodynamic variability, a tail cone with differing fin geometries can be selected by each group. Currently, there are five that are part of this project. The printing parameters can be adjusted to increase or decrease the weight of the printed tail cones.

For an inquiry-based Physics activity, your students can hypothesize about which fin design would result in a rocket traveling the highest. To conduct this lab, you can use the included presentation to support your explanations. Have your students identify the fin designs they feel would fly the highest and print those designs, with their specified infill (which will affect behavior). Once they have printed and assembled their rockets, they can measure the mass and determine the ideal height that should be reached by the rocket (as if it were flying with no drag and no losses). Once all students have reached their predictions, conduct a launch (or more, depending on your time and resources) for their rockets, with students using clinometers to measure the height reached. Make sure you have at least two students operating clinometers for every launch, in order to get more consistent results. Use trigonometry to determine the height reached (the presentation helps with this math) and compare the actual heights to the predicted. Students can be asked to identify likely causes for the differences between the two numbers.

In addition to physics applications, in both Math and Science, you can ask your students to:

  • Calculate the surface area of the tail fins that the students selected to print. The surface area has impact on drag.
  • Measure the mass of each rocket.
  • Develop hypothesis on relative performance (apogee height).
  • Observe the behavior of the rockets with twisted fins. Does the asymmetric drag help or hinder performance? (How is this related to the spin of a football?)
Rubric and Assessment

Students can be assessed on performing calculations with accuracy and in correctly applying precision and estimated units.

You can have students develop a lab report, highlighting observations, hypothesis, data collection and analysis, conclusions and future prospects and especially error analysis and communication of results.

Students can be assessed on using measuring tools with accuracy and precision. They can also be assessed on mathematical computations, graphing skills, and communicating their results. If you wish to use this project to launch a research project, assessment can be based on ELA standards as well.

Handouts and Assets:

Attached is a PDF Presentation that will help with walking students through the principles behind rocket flight and forces involved. It gives explanations of the forces and the equations of motion as well as calculations involved. Additionally, it shows how to use the clinometer and trigonometry to determine the height reached by the rocket.

References

http://www2.estesrockets.com/cgi-bin/WEDU100P.pgm
https://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/k-12/VirtualAero/BottleRocket/airplane/rktlo.html
https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/rocket/rktstab.html
https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/rocket/rktflight.html
http://www.nar.org/SandT/pdf/Estes/A8.pdf
http://motionfreefall.blogspot.com/p/kinematic-equations-for-free-fall.html
https://brainchase.com/build-clinometer/
https://www.quora.com/Sin-cos-and-tan-are-just-ratios-between-different-sides-in-a-90-angle-triangle-How-is-sin-cos-or-tan-used-to-find-the-angle-Explain-step-by-step-and-with-pictures

After Printing the Tail Section

You have to add parts to the tail section to be able to insert and remove the rocket motors. You will need one standard paperclip for this part. First, unbend the paperclip.

Once it is straightened, fold it in half, over your needle nosed pliers

Curl over the bend by gripping about 1/8 of an inch (3 mm) of it inside the pliers and bending it over.

Move about 1" (25 mm) down from the first bend and bend the clip in the opposite direction from the first bend.

Clip off the remaining paperclip, retaining about 1/4" (6 mm) of clip to project through the body of the tail section.

Step by step, it should look like this:

This shows the progression of bending for the paper clip. The last on the right is an early version of the finished part. It is best to leave 1/4 After printing the nose cone

To assemble your nose cone, insert the 5mm eye screw into the center of the base of the nose cone and follow the directions on the package from the shock cord to attach the cord and parachute to your rocket.

To put it all together:

Use white glue to affix the tail section to the toilet paper tube and allow it to dry thoroughly before launch.

Remember to be safe, wear safety glasses, maintain a safe distance, and communicate with everyone around the launch area.

Launch Controller

comments.author: peetersm

comments.text: I used natural Makerbot PLA for the tail cones. The engines do get quite warm, but do not fuse to the plastic when launched. We've done multiple launch, recover, relaunch, repeat cycles. There are a few black streaks on the interior from the ejection charge, but no damage.  The limiting factor will be physical damage due to rough handling, depending on how light you decide to print.

description.text:
I looked for a "Tag Holder" to hold the creative commons attribution tag and I could not find one. So I decided to make one.

I used Tinkercad from Autodesk. The Tag Holder can be used as is, but I added 3mm holes in
the back inside the tabs so a stand could be made. ( I will upload one sometime later)

I always wondered why nobody made one? As you are supposed to display one for
every print you make off Thingiverse when you display your prints at maker fairs etc..

Besides it looks more professional and those looking on can go directly to the exact Thingiverse page to find the item. This is what 3D printing is about after all is it not? Helping each other.
I used Scotch Wrinkle-Free Glue Stick to bind the paper to the plastic.
I imagine any glue stick would work?

Printer:

MAKERFRONT i3PRO-XL

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

80%

Notes:

I printed it face down and I use Elmer's glue on glass. That does not mean you have to.

I also used acetone smoothing on it to make it shine.

I pour some on paper towels inside a acetone proof plastic box with a lid. I made a
cardboard holder to place the part in and remove it. I cut up and bent a coat hanger
into handles and covered the cardboard in aluminum foil. I taped the coat hanger
handles to the bottom of the cardboard using duct tape before putting the aluminum
foil on. I sat it in the hot sun for 2 hours and it works fine!

comments.text: Do we need an extra to hold the tag to give appropriate credit for the holder?  (Sounds recursive to me...)  :-)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text:
It is share and share alike.
Commercial folks can use it also.
It is there for everyone to use so just the one tag inside the holder referring to whatever print you have on display.
I assure you I will not be upset.

description.text:
Project name:
Vowel blocks
Background :
• You’ll have to 3d print a fun toy.
• You’ll have to paint 5 different figures (apple, elephant, ice cream, octopus and umbrella) Paint your own toy with many different colors and have fun.
• Use soft glue on the pieces to keep them together.
• Play while learning and learn while playing
Objectives:
Have fun while printing, painting and playing.
Learn how to 3d print a figure (dimensions, technology, informatics).
Learn craft abilities like hand control, self-control, artistic skills, creativity.
Learn math skills, improve language and motor skills all by playing with different color blocks and figures.
Learn associative skills and build a strong base structure for learn how to write.
Audiences:
3 to 6 years old.
Subjects:
Art, English.
Skills learned:
Associative skills
Communication skills
Motor skills
Artistic skills
Creativity
Self-control
Math skills.

Lesson/ Activity:
• Pinrt the 5 pieces

• Paint them with your favorites colors.

• Mix colors together and get some fancy figures

• Cut 12 plastic pieces from a transparent plastic bag( ¼ inch x 4 ½ inch)

• Paste the plastic pieces JUST on the white plastic(by behind), on the left and right white plastics on the top, and on the white plastic in the middle down, the umbrella shoudn’t have any transparent plastic paste on it.

• Fold the plastic on the front of the vowel block

• Paste the transparent plastic from the vowel block below on the up side white plastic part from the vowel block stocked on it
• Repit the process, and wait 30 mainute until it dry.

Know you are ready to have fun
Just twist the vowel block on the top and Enjoy

title: Monjolo: Primitive water mill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a primitive water mill model. It a fairly simple machine that works with just water dripping. It's perfect practical lesson for kids.
This model was made to be used as an educational resource to teachers who want to discuss about physics that involve the cycle of this machine.
It can also shown how it was used in the past and is still being used today in some remote places.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Aluminum Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed with 50% scale, but ideally I designed to be built full scale, so the inertia of the water flowing down does not keep the monjolo(seesaw like object) from cycling.

Project name

Monjolo: Primitive water mill

Overview & Background

You will learn how torque works on a pivotal, free moving, seesaw-like machine.
You don't need any background to built this project.
You can go deep about into the relation between torque and the angles of the monjolo, learn more about why this machine design is so cheap and it is still being used this days at some places.

Objectives

Is expected from students that they learn about torque and its application in real world.

Audiences

You can teach this to any grade, but to teach all details about the physics behind this machine you will need to teach to at least 5th grade students.
You can also teach how to hack the monjolo(seesaw like object) adding or subtracting weight to it.
You can still teach them where did it came from and why it's so simple and cheap, and why people still using.

Subjects

History, math, physics.

Lesson/Activities

Step 1: Print the base and the monjolo, you can scale down bu not more than 70% of it original size.

Step 2: Make a dripping system
You can use any dripping system you want but keep in mind that you need to control the speed and the size of the drop need to be normal as a medicine drop.
For a constant drop you can use a soda PET bottle, a drip nozzle from 3DPonics that I will add the stl file and the link. Then you connect that nozzle to a intravenous tube that is used at the hospital. That tube usually comes with a flow regulator that you can control dripping. The picture of this device is attached if you don't know what it is.

Step 3: To put it to work, sometimes, you will have to add an extra weight as I did on my print, so that way the weight of the hammer side is heavier than the bowl side of the monjolo(seesaw like object). You can do it as you prefer. For practical purposes you can add a layer of double sided tape on top of the monjolo hammer so you can stick and take out the counterweight.

Step 4: If you did not have to stick a double sided tape you can do now if you want to stick another counter weight to teach your kids how the position of the weight affect.

Step 5: Finally put something to mill under the hammer into the base bowl.

Duration

When you pre-set this machine with the dripping mechanism all set up, you just need to set all on the table and show to your class

Preparation

This is a interactive presentation, so you don't need nothing but your students attention and curiosity.

References

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:376158/#files - Link to the 3DPonics
http://www.antonine-education.co.uk/Pages/Physics_2/Mechanics/MEC_03/Mechanics_Page_3.htm-link to torque basics
http://www.ebay.com/bhp/iv-tubing - Intravenous tubing for dripping control

https://youtu.be/byhdEwHi3wo- monjolo working

comments.text: Reminds me of how automatic rain gauges work:  two small "buckets" such that when one fills, the mechanism "tips" spilling the water out of that "bucket" and bringing the other "bucket" into the stream.  ("Tips" are usually counted electronically these days, but it would be conceivable to count them mechanically.)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: When people talk about clever and pratical automatic machines they usually remenber about electronics and all its sensor. But those mechanic machines are way clever when you need tô be practical, cheap and some cases also more reliable.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

title: Pentadecathlon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 3D visualization of an "oscillator" from Conway's Game of Life. This loop is called the "pentadecathlon.".
Each layer is a different stage of the oscillator. The angled parts were added to support each level.

The version pictured is the one cycle version. It was scaled up by 150%.
The loop version can be copied and pasted on top of itself, or sliced to start on a different stage.

title: LEGO Mindstorms 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jE28C7Z6KX8

This is a LEGO MINDSTORMS 3D printer I made with a 3D pen, and a custom g-code interpiter. It uses four LEGO MINDSTORMS motors. Three on the motors are for the axis, and the fourth controls the extruder. I chose the 3D I'm using because it took 1.75 mm filament in spool form, and was quite cheap at around $50 USD(Now It's $31.90 USD!). This project is great to teach a class how to build 3D a printer with much less of a risk of burns, damaging electronics, or damaging mechanical parts.

You can find the pen here:

http://www.amazon.com/Soyan-Drawing-Printing-Printer-Filament/dp/B00PTW7WEQ

g-pars3 is available for free on GitHub.

Check it out here:

https://github.com/cyruscuenca/g-pars3

I have instructions on how to use the g-code interpiter on my blog.

Check that out here:

http://cyruscuenca.blogspot.com/2016/06/g-pars3-beta-available.html

Information for MakerEd Challenge:

Skills learned:

The basics of how to build a 3D printer, structural engineering, code navigation,

Items needed:

LEGO Mindstorms EV3:

http://www.lego.com/en-us/mindstorms/products/mindstorms-ev3-31313

3D Pen:

http://www.amazon.com/Soyan-Drawing-Printing-Printer-Filament/dp/B00PTW7WEQ

Extra LEGOs:

http://bricklink.com
http://brickowl.com

g-pars3:

http://github.com/cyruscuenca/g-pars3

Project duration:

1 - 3 weeks depending on how many hours you have per day, and shipping time.

Preparation:

Students and teachers should know how to safely deal with plugs.

Teacher must have reasonable computer skills(UI).

It would be good if the teacher had a basic understanding of how code works.

References:

Check out my blog for updates about this project, and keep an eye on the README.md on the G-PARS3 GitHub repository.

Rubric & Assessment:

Students should:

• Have a functional printer
• Be able to print with the printer

Grading:

You could grade based on the most complex object the students printed, print quality, print time, and design practicality.

Handouts & Assets:

N/A
Results

Step 1 • Build Hardware

The actual printer is just like any other cartesian 3D printer.

You must have three axis:

Z (Up and down)
X (Left and right)
Y (Forward and backwards)
And you need to have the fourth motor press the extrude button on the 3D pen.

Some building tips:

Reinforce corners with triangles when possible
Use smaller gears if you are running a platform along gear racks
Use the LEGO frames when you can

Step 2 • Program the EV3 Brick

Use the instructions here:
http://cyruscuenca.blogspot.com/2016/06/g-pars3-beta-available.html

Step 3 • Calibrate and print

If your pen gets stuck during prints, increase the thickness of layers.

The pen has extrusion speed control. Use the slider to increase extrusion speed, and then increase movement speed in g-pars3.

description.text:
My wife wanted to hang curtains around our backyard patio. However, we couldn't find any strong, seemless, weatherproof, metal curtain rods. So, we bought some 1" galvanized steel pipe from Home Depot along with some 1" curtain rod holders (hooks?).

We have a 14 foot section on our patio and the longest pipe we could find was 10 feet. So, I made this little coupler to join two sections of pipe together.

The coupler is designed so that you should be able to twist each pipe on clockwise. Just make sure you get roughly half of the coupler in each pipe.

NOTE! This is not meant to support the full weight of a 10 foot steel pipe (you're printing plastic, you know!?). When you connect two pipes together, make sure you support it on both ends. Also, make sure your curtain rod supports are positioned to support each pole properly.

Printer:

Flux Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Depending on the pipe you buy, you may have to scale the diameter (x & y dimensions) by a little bit. This size worked for me with the pipe I bought and my two printers. YMMV.

Any resolution should work. You won't see the part, so a fast print at a low resolution should be fine.

TIP! When checking the size, print this about 10mm tall instead of the full 50mm. 10mm is enough to check the fit, but it prints pretty quickly (about 10-15 minutes, depending on your printer settings).

comments.text:
Just a tip:
If you fit one short wooden piece of rod into the tube ends it will increase the stability very much.
It could be 3D printed but I think wood might be better.
comments.author: dude_lbot

comments.text: Yeah, I tried several ways to do it: this, a completely solid one of these, one of these with a smaller steel pipe in it, and just a wood dowel. Anyway, this works, but it's fragile. Something stronger than plastic is really the way to go.

description.text:
WARNING! These models are not suitable for real world use out of the box as a 3D printed item. A better though untested option would be using these printed models to make a mold and then casting the models using a more suitable material.

This was designed around one of the yellow plastic shells. Tapered style powder pocket holds 40 grains of black powder. This bushing must be epoxied or somehow semi-permanently affixed to the shell casing. These are currently UNTESTED. I take no responsibility for the use or misuse of this file. 3D printed materials tend to be weak and it may be dangerous to actually use 3D printed parts in this manner, making molds and castings based off these prints may be a better option. Use at your own discretion. Be safe with your reloading.

Please TIP if you like this file so I can devote more time to designing similar models!

title: CHIP, The 9 Dollar Computer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a model of CHIP The Nine Dollar Computer for you to use when building models for CHIP cases or accessories. It is not intended to be printed.

I want to design some cases for CHIP and I usually model a subject before I model accessories for it. Until I had the CHIP board in hand, I couldn't design a case because I didn't know its exact dimensions.

I'm sharing it for everyone else who might want to build accessories for CHIP. Now that I have modeled it, anyone should be able to make a case for it very easily.

Model dimensions were measured in 1/10 mm intervals.

I have seen several revisions of the board on the CHIP website. I assume that my board is the final production design and there are no other versions of it in the public's hands. If someone finds that is not the case, please let me know in the comments!

One of the challenges in building a case is knowing the contact points where you can apply pressure without damaging any components.

CHIP employs some of the tiniest surface-mount electronic components around. There are so many and they are so hard to see and they are so dense that even if you can be sure you've found a spot free of components it would be so small that you may not be able to produce a case with enough precision to utilize it. Any inaccuracy could result if damage to a nearby SMD.

I could never accurately model all the tiny components on the CHIP board. Never. Instead, I just marked the entire board blue (indicating sensitive components and therefore off-limits and made note of the following exceptions, which should be safe for contact with the case:

  • The single screw mount hole in the corner next to the USB port and its surrounding copper pad, obviously.
  • The four side edges of the circuit board (not the top or bottom surfaces, just the thin side edge).
  • The top of any peripheral connectors on the edge of the board (USB, micro USB power, composite video, JST-PH battery socket, I/O header sockets, if not being used). Excessive pressures may deform sockets and prohibit operation, especially the JST_PH socket. It's best to have contact pressures on the BACK of the socket, rather than the front.
  • The top and bottom of the IO header sockets (the long, tall black rows).
  • The red zones indicated in the uploaded images of the model.

The pins of the headers did not appear to be soldered, but rather compression-fit into the vias. I worry that too much pressure on the bottom of the header pins and any downward pressure elsewhere may cause the header connection to become unreliable or even cause the header to pop off the board. Be sure to put opposing downward pressures on the top and bottom of the IO header to avoid this. If you expose the I/O headers, it's best not to put any pressure below them.

Because STLs don't support color, I have provided the two screen shots of the top and bottom of the model before exporting to STL. The first is an actual model of the CHIP. The second has blue regions to indicate off-limits areas occupied by SMDs and red zones to indicate possible safe zones for contact.

Because STLs don't inherently support color, I have raised the blue and red zones by 0.1 mm so that you can see them in the model. You'll have to refer to the photos to figure out what each zone's color is, unfortunately. If anyone has a better idea about how to handle this, please leave a comment.

Color scheme:

  • Orange / gold are bare metal copper pads, through-hole pins or other electrical contact exposure.
  • Dark gray are silver or chrome colored connectors
  • Light gray are large protruding components (inductors).
  • Dark blue are various surface mount components. Height may vary but most are 1mm or shorter. Most of the blue region is a careless blanket but I was very careful to model them accurately near the back edge and near the red zones.
  • Green is used when modeling the RealTek slave board. It is actually green on the CHIP mainboard with a black RealTek package on the top so those are the colors I used.
  • Black are semiconductors. Many of the small ones appear to be transistors, FETs or power regulators. The larger ones are memory, CPU, or other components. I've modeled every single one of these so that you know where they are for heat considerations when building a case. You'll know where someone might put a heatsink or where airflow may be most important. However, I don't know which of these chips will have a tendency to get hot, so that's for you to worry about :)

title: MRM Reaper VTX & Vertical Antenna Mount

description.text:
Here are the Video Transmitter and Vertical Antenna Mounts for the MRM Reaper frames.
http://www.multirotormania.com/200mm-smaller-micro/1448-mrm-reaper-195220-fpv-racing-frame.html

These Mounts are designed to be printed in TPU!! Printing in a Rigid material (PLA, ABS, etc.) will not result in a functioning part.

The antenna mount slides over the rear standoffs and fits around the frame/Arms. The VTX mount is designed to fit over the standoffs above the antenna mount.

Using the Vertical antenna mount requires a VTX with a 90 degree pigtail installed. This mount protects the antenna from damage in a crash. The TPU allows the mount to flex, saving the SMA connectors from being ripped off the antenna/VTX. Choose the Antenna mount file by the arm type you have. The profiles differ slightly.

UPDATE:
Added 3 different Vert Antenna Mounts to suit the slightly different arm profiles. The 195 4mm profile should be universal, but if you want the best fit, choose the one that fits your arms.

UPDATE 2:
Added 2 new 5mm antenna mounts. These add clearance for larger VTX, like the Foxeer FX799t, decased cricket or Luminere, etc. The VTX can slip below the top of the antenna mount now. The Large allows 5 x 23mm to pass thru, and the Xtra-Large allows 6.5 x 23mm.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 20 Microns

Infill:

35% on Antenna Mount 100% on VTX mount

print_settings.Notes:: Infill % shouldn't affect the flexible filament, but make sure that your perimeters are 1.2mm so that the slicer doesn't try to put infill inside the flex springs.

description.text:
UPDATE 8.30.2016: Just uploaded V9 of this design, although I will leave the old version up as well. V9 removes some of the flex filament that made up the springs and only includes it in a strip along the back, which reduces the amount of force required to contract the finger. It will also probably extend the life of the part because there is much less TPU being moved.

I created this design because I was curious about the potential for combining flexible filament with stiff PLA. Thermoplastic polyurethane or TPU comes out of the extruder slightly tacky. Once cooled it doesn't stretch, but will flex and bend when force is applied returning to its original position afterwards. My idea was to incorporate a flexible joint with stiff structure to make it bend in predictable ways.

This my first design using TPU, so I decided to make something that I could test simply. After several versions figuring out print settings and rules of thumb for flexible filament I made a quick edit to test the finger out using a Raptor Reloaded from the e-NABLE foundation . Later on I would like to design a solution that incorporates flexible filament in the entire prosthetic, but this is a start.

Printer:

Modified Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used Hatchbox PLA and Sainsmart SemiFlex TPU on my own printer which uses an E3D Cyclops mixing extruder.

Infill % shouldn't affect the flexible filament, but make sure that your perimeters are 1.2mm so that the slicer doesn't try to put infill inside the flex springs.

After being removed from the printer and getting cleaned up a little bit, you can attach the finger to a Raptor Reloaded hand. Stringing & tensioners work just like in their tutorial, except that you don't have as many parts. I have had success using nylon coated wire, alternatives like fishing line were too thin and caused layers to split or crack.

Demonstrating the key grip with V8 of the flex finger. The squeaking is from the nylon scraping against the plastic of the Raptor Reloaded palm (which I'll fix later, honest!).

I designed the part in Fusion 360, sliced it in Cura and printed it out on my prusa i3 using an E3D Cyclops to handle the dual extrusion. In my later designs I decided to trap the stiff filament inside flexible filament to reduce retraction and stringing.

Preliminary tests are promising! I'm looking at ways to reduce the amount of flexible filament used. This would allow me to save material as well as making the finger take less force to close.

title: Heavy load car for LGB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a part designed for the LGB heavy load car number 40580. I had the middle part (bought from spares when LGB went bancrupt) but not the front and rear bogie frame work of the car, so I decided to create them. LGB trucks and axels will fit the frames. When I get time I will also design the bogies and the middle part so you can create a complete heavy load car. Mine is already running on our layout (see picture with tank). The complete file is just for reference. Enjoy!

2016-09-30: I've added bogies and wheels (also LGB wheel will fit). You will need 4 pcs of 70mm long steel shafts, 3mm in diameter. The bogies are glued together. Use the mounting help to get the correct distances. Put the mounting help on the table, insert the shaft, add the first wheel, insert "wheel_middle", add the second wheel and remove the mounting help. You need to drill all holes in correct 3mm diameter. I've also corrected a small misstake I made in the frame model. The new complete file also includes the bogies.

description.text: I made this for my feeder crickets. i keep it in my chameleons cage. It fits a regular sponge and has a cover.

First attempt at a Bruder styled toy.

The end-caps have a slot to insert an M6 threaded nylon nut.
I used a piece of scrap PVC tubing 50mm diameter x 1.5mm thickness and 144mm long. Glued one end-cap in place, filled the tube with sand for extra weight, then glued the second end-cap.

Connected the roller to the frame with M6 bolts.
Strong and light.  Flat or double-sided.  Enjoy!

Thanks

18/02-2018

Reworked for greather strenght!
Now with extra part for strength works a lot better!

New version, had some problems assembling the first one.

This is a remix of Rock75 version, where he made room for the genius Titan extruder!
I also wanted to mount the BLTouch sensor.

Changes to gantry= holes moved for belts, grove made for BLTouch

WARNING your printer needs to be calibrated well

This is my second EVER try of designing anything, so it is a work in process, I THINK it will work, but I still need to build the gantry to the printer, and wire it all up, since I am still in the mid of the build ;-)

Sorry it does not look pretty, but I have NO idea what Í am doing ;-) but I just made my test assembly nr.9 and it seems to work well and tight.
IF I can get this to work, Ill assemble the printer with this setup and print new parts (better looking, and heated champer!!)

I will also be working on a new fan, blowing from 4 sides is my goal.

You are welcome to improve, change, have fun! just show and link your result, so we can get the best gantry at the end :-)

Made for the http://www.eclips3d.com/

Look out for upgrades :-)
Regards Jesper

Why this?

When I decided to build a new printer, I knew it should be super quality, at low price..
after using a lot of time searching, I found the http://www.eclips3d.com/ and decided that this should be my next printer. though I would save the cost of the expensive computer, and instead use the money on:
Titan extruder, Pancake steppermotor and BLTouch sensor!!

I wrote on the great forum of the Eclips3d and during a short time, 2 sugestions was up, for the gantry, with room for the Titan extruder. BUT no one had the time/need for mounting a BLTouch sensor. SO I decided to give it a go, and this is the result!
please bare with me, or even improve it... I have used around 10-15 hours designing this, due to me not knowing how to do it! BUT this should be working, not pretty BUT working :-)

Tell us more...

description.text:
Helper discs... YAY!

Use them in your slicer or modeling software to help prevent sharp edges from lifting off the print bed during printing due to cooling/shrinkage. ALL helper discs are 0.30mm thick, allowing for easy trimming & cleanup. If you want to make them thicker, you can "Scale the Z" based on 0.30 mm starting thickness 50% =0.15mm thick, 133%~0.40mm thick, and 166%~0.5mm thick... etc.
Simply place them under any sharp edges prior to slicing and print!

Sizes include 30mm, 20mm (OD) with 5mm & 10mm holes in each, and 10mm (OD) with 2.5mm & 5mm holes. All discs also have Have the following revolutions: 1/4 (1qtr), 1/2 (half), 3/4 (3qtr), and full revolutions to help you to select the best one for printing your parts.

I created these STL's after watching them used on a "How to prevent your parts from lifting off the bed" video. These are also called "Mouse Ears", or "tabs".

It would be GREAT to have the 3D slicer software makers pick up something like this WITHIN their software.
What I'd suggest if a software designer is reading this:
1) Would like to say anything with major horizontal angles on the bed over some user customizable angle (45°, with straight lines being 0° and a right angle either way being 90°). 2) Tabs could be changed but would be default to .30mm, or two print layers thick.
3) Option to use tabs on inside corners.
4) Option to use tabs on Internal outside corners (an obtuse angle within the exterior perimeter of the part).
5) Option to select sizing options and user place them (like the support tab like most softwares accomodate).

Just in case that never happens... just use these as a part and place them to your hearts content.

~Enjoy!

It can be used stand alone or with piston.

No

Notes:

Use brim for all parts. Print tension device and tent peg 3 times. You will also need 10mm thread drill and 3 aluminum tubes 1m or 1,2m long diameter 15mm with 1,5mm thick walls and 5m long 1,8mm rope.

Glue tubes to top and bottom part with epoxy glue. Attach rope to top part and tension device and you are ready to use tower for launching device. I case of using piston launcher , just drill M10 thread. If you don't own piston, you can print igniter holder (my advice is to put some aluminum tape on top of holder) and just insert it into hole.

Permet de positionner la batterie Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh à l’extérieur du boitier pour éviter les parasites et améliorer le refroidissement du système (pas testé avec une batterie 2000mAh mais étant normalement plus petite ça devrait rentrer sans soucis) .

4 vis têtes fraisées pas mécanique 4mm x 20mm.
4 écrous diamètre 4 mm.
4 rondelles diamètre 4 mm.
Double face pour maintenir les micro switchs .

-Positionner le boitier sans le couvercle en face des trous de la PiGRRL2 et coller les switchs, l’idéal est au centre du logement des boutons .
-Prendre le boitier en mains viser les 4 vis dans le couvercle et dans celui ci .
-Insérer la batterie dans la boitier sans oublier de passer le fil dans le trou.
-Plaquer le tous et viser les écrous a l 'intérieur de la PiGRRL2 sans serrer trop fort.

Il est tout a fait possible d' installer le boitier sur une PiGRRL2 non modifiée, il faut alors percer et ajuster les trous pour permettre le passage des fils, il faut aussi limer les deux supports de vis du haut (ceux permettant la fixation de la plaque des switchs arrières ).

title: 500mm quadcopter, fully enclosed, gopro mount built in, vibration dampened flight board, battery slide and hood

description.text:
This is our first upload of our quadcopter design, about its 12th revision though. Features:
  • motor cabling through 12mm arms
  • slide on battery clip
  • vibration dampened flight board (effectively kills all vibrations to accelerometer)
  • designed for 4 in 1 hobbywing esc
  • extremely strong
  • motor mounts have built in hidden hole for leds to light up the plastic for orientation
  • very lightweight
  • totally enclosed with hinged hood
  • gopro mount built in
  • landing gear uses same tube as arms, locks over frame, cheap/light/effective
  • general purpose cargo slot
    • The whole thing is designed to take 12mm diameter aluminium or carbon fibre arms, roughly 250mm length each. needs 4 m3 bolts and nyloc nuts to secure the arms to the frame and 4 m3 bolts and nuts to secure the motor mounts to the arms. Landing gear is fastened using cable ties.

you need:
12mm tube (carbon or alum) (2meters) cut into 250mm lengths
8 m3 bolts
8m3 nyloc nuts
8 small cable ties
1 elastic band
2 small foam pads for flight board Printer settings:
We printed everything on a UP! mini printer, in ABS, fine resolution, 0.2mm layer height, with like 25% fill. Plenty strong, have flown full speed into a tree and the aluminium bent, no cracked plastic. the main chassis piece needs to be printer in the orientation that the quad would fly in, that is, battery slide down. the landing gear pieces all need printing vertically, the motor mounts on their side as is shown in the render above. battery clip and flight board holder printed flat as well. hood should be printed upside down to minimise support material. the holes on the flight board holder are spaced at 45mm x 45mm. Good luck! Config for our quad:
750kv ax-2810q
11x4.7 (used to be 12x4.5, less efficient)
arducopter (megapirate) 3.0.1
ublox gps
turnigy er9x
turnigy 2x2200mah 20C 3s parallel
3dr 915mhz telemetry
30a x 4 all in 1 esc. stay tuned for photos...

author: chev383

description.text:
This 2.4 GHz biquad yagi is Inspired by Andrew McNeil's YouTube channel dedicated primarily to antenna design and testing.

Check out the Biquad Yagi Customizer to create an antenna of your own design.

Thanks to Thingerverse user djinc3ption, there is some excellent test data done in an anechoic chamber. Check out the VSWR, Frequency Responce, and 3D propagation graphs, and a link to the raw test data on his make page.

This antenna design uses solid 14 gauge (~1.7mm) copper wire. The 27mm element is the first parasitic element followed by 28mm, 29mm, 30mm, then the 31.5mm driven element and a 34mm reflector at the rear (these are all outside dimensions). I have added cylinders with a closed end for attaching a solid reflector and/or base station mount. I made a reflector out of a piece of thin 56 mm x 110 mm sheet metal with drilled holes for small screws and a larger hole with a rubber grommet to pass the coax cable through. The parasitic elements are spaced 17mm apart with the reflector spaced 19 mm from the driven element. These dimensions are taken directly from Andrew's PCB biquad yagi design. I used a short length of flexible coax cable with an sma connector to connect the antenna to my usb wifi adaptor.

Have a look at the video that inspired this design here: Biquad Yagi 2 4GHz and 5 8GHz Upgrade!

comments.text: Thank you so much for this! This is so awesome... on the road to perfection.
comments.author: dotslash

comments.text: Hi dotslash,
comments.author: dotslash

comments.text: I did a lot of antenna theory 30 years ago, so I'm a bit rusty... got a couple of questions:
comments.author: Graveling

comments.text: If you've taken any antenna theory, you likely already know more than me, but I'll have a go at it anyway.  The theoretical optimal outside dimensions of the driven element for a 1.4GHz biquad yagi would be 53.53 mm.  The best I can do from here is practical guesswork, and assumptions. So, given that this 2.4 GHz antenna design has been tested to have a peak response at 2.442 GHz, and assuming that everything can be directly scaled to 1.4 GHz (a big assumption), than 54.945 mm is the practical optimal dimension for the driven element.  That is ((31.5 * 2442) / 1400), or a ratio of ~1:1.74429.  That would make the first parasitic element 47.1 mm, the second 48.84 mm, the third 50.58 mm, and the fourth 52.33 mm, with a 59.31 mm reflector.  Element spacing would be 29.65 mm, with 33.14mm between the driven element and the reflector.  Your elements would use 2.8 mm copper wire (~9 AWG) or thicker depending on the bandwidth required.  This is a ridiculously simplified conversion, but I'm guessing it would get you pretty close.  The only way to know would be to build it and test it in an anechoic chamber.  At least then you would know what adjustments need to be made.
comments.author: Graveling

comments.text:

I'm using slicer so I'll just do a scale of 1.74. It doesnt have to be spot on (well, ideally it does, but for this it doesnt matter). I believe I should be able to use the 2.4ghz and use it as a half wave(?) for 1.2ghz, which will be ok for some stuff. Scaling it up by 1.74 uses a lot of filament, so I might print a template a few layers thick of each element and use some cheaper media.

Hello.
I tried making this antenna but it doesn't work. I followed all the instructions but the reception it's pretty bad. I even used a really short coaxial cable. I feel disappointed :(
comments.author: Freeman77

comments.text: I'd like to help if I can.  What steps have you taken to troubleshoot your antenna's poor performance?  Do yo have another 2.4 GHz antenna to compare reception with?  Have you checked your print for dimensional accuracy?  If the dimensions aren't accurate, the antenna will be tuned to a frequency other than 2.4 GHz.  If you haven't already done so, use a multimeter to check for electrical continuity from the connector to the antenna.  If the the centre pin and the outer rim of the connector have good connections to the antenna but your antenna is still performing poorly, check to see if the cable has a solder bridge where it connects to the antenna.  It is also possible that the insulator around the inner conductor of the cable has melted during soldering, resulting in an electrical short.  You can also post a "make page" with some detailed photos and I may be able to spot any issues.
comments.author: Freeman77

comments.text: Thank you for your reply. I posted a "make" of the antenna describing everything I did.

The parasitic elements have no electrical connection with one another.  The only connection is a coaxial cable soldered to the driven element.

comments.author: vVict0rx

comments.text: Have you uploaded the new files since then? I would love to print a final version ;-)
comments.author: ReallyBigTeeth

comments.text: I have.  It wasn't a big change. I just closed off one end of the tubes so that a sheet metal reflector and/or a mount of some kind could be attached with screws.  I included a couple photos of the antenna with a solid reflector instead of the 34 mm wire reflector.  The dimensions of the elements are all the same.  djinc3ption did some antenna analysis in an anechoic chamber and found the tuning to be dead centre of the 2.4 GHz wifi band, so no changes were necessary there.  The only change that I would recommend is to increase the spacing between the elements a little if you want a stronger signal for the lower and upper channels.  The spacing I outlined on the design page makes the antenna a little narrow banded; great if your trying to pull in channel 6 or 7 but the frequency response becomes less optimal the further from centre frequency you get.

author: chev383

description.text:
The Z-stage for the Ultimaker 3D printer is made up of layered pieces of plywood that clamp around LMU12LUU linear bearings. That construction results in an unstable Z-stage, either due to movement of the bearings in their seats, or movement due to moisture content levels in the wood itself.
This design does away with the LMU12LUU bearings and replaces them with LMK12LUU bearings that offer a flange to attach the (perpendicular) platform. Furthermore, the plywood is replaced by 10mm acrylic, to avoid warping due to changes in moisture content.
It has 4 tapped holes to mount the regular Ultimaker built platform (10mm acrylic). This is very much a work in progress, as I have not made one yet!
This thing is shared with a CC-BY-SA license with a special exception, see license.txt for details.

Needed parts:
2 LMK12LUU linear bearings. this is the double-long version, 60mm tall, capped by a square flange at the end. A rounded or flat-rounded flange variant may also work, you may need to modify the mounting holes for these.
3 printed parts: the nut-holder, the compensating slide and the slide pin. Print these with as much precision as you can: too much roughness on them will prevent XY movement of the leadscrew nut, leading to small disturbances in the Z direction ('Z wobble).
Mill out the platform part out of Suitably thick Acrylic, Trespa or any other suitably stiff material. Drill all holes with 2.5mm drill and tap with a M3 tap. Assemble and mount in your Ultimaker. You may need to defer tightening the bolts attaching the bearings, to allow them to absorb small size variations.

comments.text: Do you have any photos of the revised Z-stage? I'd love to see it assembled.
comments.author: czucker

comments.text: yes it works. even 10mm acrylic is a bit flexible though, but not too bad. I had to adapt the nutholder so it gives more space for the Z-coupler at the bottom. The holes for the bearings were too tight, the total height of the construction can be 10mm less if you stick the bearings trough the acrylic. It still needs a trigger for the Z-endstop, that should not be too hard to mount to one of the bearings.

print_settings.Notes:: I also HIGHLY recommend using the strongest material you can, such as ABS (if you can print without warping) or perhaps PETG (I've never used it, but heard it's appropriate)

description.text:
This print is my best attempt at the easiest possible quad frame to print and assemble with viable durability and weight for beginner to intermediate racing. Carbon racing frames can cost about $100 for a good one, so I hope that by potentially printing this frame for about 2 dollars of plastic that might help people enter the quad racing sport at a lower barrier of entry (cost-wise).

The design features a central battery bay, placing the heaviest component of the quad in between all the motors for a solid centre of gravity negating sloppy handling which can occur due to a pendulum effect caused by having the battery above or bellow the frame.

The battery is also very well crash protected in this configuration, minimising risk of fires.
The design features pitched motors and also stepped back motors which should result in less turbulent air being fed into the rear motors which then should result in more consistent thrust and steadier control.

I really enjoyed flying my print of this frame before it broke, and I hope it's helpful to someone out there, God bless.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

no lower than 25%

Notes:

Since this print is large and attaching your electrical components is very time consuming I HIGHLY recommend disregarding the weight you may save from a lower infill value and instead printing all parts with an infill of 50% or more, ideally 100% solid.

I also HIGHLY recommend using the strongest material you can, such as ABS (if you can print without warping) or perhaps PETG (I've never used it, but heard it's appropriate)

For the full development diary, check out the RC groups thread here.
http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2657583

The design has evolved out of many attempts at making a durable 3D printed racing quad frame. It takes some inspiration from the design of the Carbon Hornet 2B by Revolution Aerial.

author: born22000

description.text:
This is a direct extruder from the original parts of the Eventorbot kit. It rides on top of the X-axis. Upgrade:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227289 This is a new filament guide worked in the existing hinge structure. This simplifies the whole extruder and makes it more stable and incorporates the newest experiences I had with it. One final change will be the shift of the hinge axis under or behind the drive gear so that the filament pressure cant lift the motor up anymore. This should be reduced with the new filament guide but would be the ideal solution.

-Printed with 2 shells and 25% infill.
-The front plate goes on the existing metal hotend bracket. M2.5 screws fit barely through the holes in the original hothead bracket.
-The hinges have holes for M5 screws. Im using an old screw from the bed.
-The motor incl. bracket and filament guide, can be screwed in with the original screws but flipped 180deg (dont forget to switch the motor direction in the firmware) or use the upgrade.
-The 2 holes behind the motor and in the new brace are for small rollers in found in my hardware store, but they could be redesigned to fit normal round bearings.
-For now Im using PLA because its stiffer. I didnt experience any heat deformations.
-When using slicer the scaling factor is 1000%.

author: moose4621

description.text:
This upgrade part is designed to enhance your mousetraps, making it more likely that the mouse will trigger the trap while going after the bait. Very effective when you have tiny, ninja mice who take the bait without triggering the trap.

Check it out on my Blog Post here:
https://teslaandi.wordpress.com/2016/07/03/if-people-just-designed-things-right-to-begin-with-2-2

I recommend the Square Beta cage, as it prints better and is harder for the mouse to get past.

Simply fill the printed cage with cheese, attractant, ham, or whatever your pests will eat. Then slide the cage onto the lever of your mousetrap (where you would normally put the cheese), and set the trap as normal.

This upgrade works by making the mouse poke its nose between the bars of the cage, applying some force to the lever, triggering it.

(the design opening is to fit 10 mm wide x 1mm thick mousetrap levers)

Note: I will not be held responsible if by using this upgrade you accidentally kill off all the less ninja-like mice, leaving only a rapidly evolving race of super mice. You have been warned.

comments.text: I’ve had a little ninja of my own and this enhancer KO’d the little thief the first night. Great design (beta) and fits and works as advertised. Thank you.   Plus we had one without the enhancer baited the same way alongside, it was picked clean and never popped. Good test in my opinion.
comments.author: vinopilot

comments.text: interesting solution to a real problem.  We use peanut butter and wrap it several times with thread and tie the ends together.  I assumed they tried to get every last bit off the thread and/or thread got caught in their teeth a bit and when they tried to get it out....  works every time, too.
comments.author: JustForFun

title: Mini Nintendo NES case for Raspberry Pi 3 B

description.text:
This is a remake of the BabyNES Raspberry Pi B+ case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:449877

This case fits for the actual Raspberry Pi 3 Model B. Some gaps are included so the pcb lies flat on the holding blocks. Also the screw guides at the top part of the case are made more stable.

The top and bottom part of the case are hold together with 4 M3x20mm screws. It can be necessary that the holes have to be drilled up a little bit.

Part List

Raspberry Pi 3 Model B (Rev 1.2 or newer)
5V 2.5A Power Supply with a male Micro-USB plug.
Micro SD card (16-64 GB)
HDMI Cable
Wireless (Gasia / Shanwan) or Wired Gamepad

Software

The firmware which is used in this project is called RetroPie. RetroPie can be downloaded here: https://retropie.org.uk/

From https://retropie.org.uk/:
It builds upon Raspbian, EmulationStation, RetroArch and many other projects to enable you to play your favourite Arcade, home-console, and classic PC games with the minimum set-up.

For further informations have a look at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:449877
and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307832

Update:

Filament Fuser joiner Version 0.6 Released !

Now with more Safety Features

Fan Warning Message when loading ..
Check of Temperature Sensor
Warm up countdown on Sensor
Added Resettable fuse on electronics
Added Ground lead for better Earthing on Hot end

Available on my Tindie page Now @ SUPER low Price !!

I ended up with several rolls of PLA , looking for a suitable solution on the net did produce any fruitful results, so i designed my own ..

Features:

Knob to set temperature desired - top from 0 to 300 degrees - Fahrenheit option available !
Hot end switching to reach temp with sensor connected to stabilise it

can be used with the fiament fuser http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656353

Safety feature : knob all to the left will switch off the heater .. display shows off ..

Tested ..

author: thewhitebear

title: Vase - 16 pointed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Experimenting with twisting lofts in Onshape, cane up with this vase design. The print in the photos was scaled 125% in the Z direction only.

My spool was binding a bit at the end so the photo has shows some cracks in the layer adhesion.

Printed in glow-in-the-dark (very weakly) PETG from MakerGeeks. Was on sale, so can't complain to much.

Scaled might make nice LED tealight holders.

Timelapse of the print: https://youtu.be/8XWSvPbybXo

Printer:

i300 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm - 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Vase mode. 3 bottom layers. No top.

Yes, my printer has noticeable z-banding. It's a feature I wanted--yeah, that's the ticket.
(Ball screws shouldn't do this, and eventually will find a way to minimize it--taking suggestions.)
No apparent twist feature n Onshape so working on some experiments using the lofting feature.

author: idig3d

print_settings.Notes:: Print as oriented in .STL file with supports. Be careful to only use support you can actually extract afterwards.

description.text:
The best cooling for Velleman K8200.

Use High temp silicone to fill the gap between metal and plastic in the fan-chamber for the PTFE part. No air should find it's way down to the heated part of the hotend.

(Super)glue the left part of the part to the bottom of the mounting bracket for the extruder.

Use glue(hotglue) to fasten fans

Made for two 40x40x20 blower fans in the back, and one 40x40 fan in front

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

Not an issue

Notes:

Print as oriented in .STL file with supports. Be careful to only use support you can actually extract afterwards.

comments.text: Good thinking :) And yes, the K8200 is not a good z-axis machine... But I get desent prints as long as I keep the pressure on the z-axis rod at just the right spot. Do not ask what that means, cuz it only means i adjust the tension on the top nut juuuuuuuust right, and it works.. ;)

comments.author: Ott3rman

comments.text: Normal 40x40 fan in front yes. The reason for two fans in the back is to move enough air through the chamber to actively cool. I have not really tried with one of these fans only, but feel free to try. Just blank of the other hole with a piece of tape or something. Both fans blow into the same chamber, so it does not matter what fan you blank of.
